docs.title: Technology Journeys
docs.text:
This website is a memoir of my Technology journeys.

As a lifelong technology enthusiast, I begin my day by using an RSS (Really Simple Syndication) computer application. This application queries selected websites to discover new web postings, and I only save the most intriguing bookmarks for future reference.

Throughout my career, I’ve had technology journeys, including consulting, management, engineering, and individual contributions including hardware and software development, project management, and project rescue, includong analyze and monitor the performance of hardware, networks, software, and web technologies.

docs.title: Electronic Components
docs.text: The journey began with receiving an Allied Electronics catalog, sparking interest in both familiar and new components.

docs.title: Learning Resources
docs.text:
I expanded my knowledge through subscriptions to weekly and monthly electronics periodicals, which introduced new components and equipment and provided application insights.

Bookstores, both local and in other cities, served as important sources of new books for my growing technical library, although some books were occasionally outdated.

The Internet and Artificial Intelligence were transformative for technology learning, replacing the manual collection and analysis of information from varied sources.

Utilizing an RSS (Really Simple Syndication) Internet application daily enables track technologies of interest.

docs.title: Radio Journeys
docs.text: My radio journey commenced with the family multiband radio that included some amateur radio and foreign broadcast bands. I particularly enjoyed listening to Voice of America, South American, Australian, and others stations. Listening to amateur radio bands also piqued my interest.

docs.title: Amater Radio
docs.text: Learning about basic radios And transmitters at the city library, and building a crystal radio able to receive local AM signals without external power.

docs.title: Licensing
docs.text: Studying and passing FCC tests for novice and general amateur radio licenses, with a focus on Morse Code practicing reception and transmission using a homemade transistor audio oscillator and Morse key.

docs.title: Commercial License
docs.text: My next journey was studing for and taking the Federal Communications Commission test for a First Class Commercial license required for those responsible for operating and maintaining broadcast transmitters, especially as a chief engineer at a broadcast station or for work on television transmitters.

docs.title: Junior College
docs.text:
My academic journey in electronic engineering commenced during my enrollment at a technology junior college.

During my studies, I continued a keen interest in electronic components and the utilization of electronic instruments, particularly oscilloscopes.

I thoroughly enjoyed electronic circuits, components, vacuum tubes and transistors classes. Laboratories involved constructing circuits and measuring various electronic parameters.

docs.title: Engineering College
docs.text: My subsequent academic pursuit in electronic engineering entailed enrolling in a four-year Electronics Engineering Bachelor Degree program.

docs.title: Math and Science
docs.text: In parallel with Electronic Engineering classes, mathematics and physics classes were aligned with Electronic Engineering theory classes

docs.title: Circuit Analysis Software
docs.text: An intriguing aspect of one class was to describe a circuit to an electronic circuit analysis software program that analyzed circuits and printed out computed parameters. The results of the circuit I described were a significant revelation for me.

docs.title: Electromagnetic Interference (EMI)
docs.text: The success of physical circuit design is influenced by the physical reality of component tolerances and EMI generated by component or circuits unintentionally affecting the operation of other components or circuits. EMI is usually difficult to measure and mitigate.

docs.title: Software
docs.text: Software engineering is eaiser to mitigate errors being more traceable and fixable compared to hardware EMI.

docs.title: Senior Project
docs.text:
The final year of Electronic Engineering classes included designing, developing, and documenting a Senior Project before graduation.

I developed a Fortran program using Fourier transforms to analyze waveforms, with verification using lab instruments, and oscilloscope calibration.
